skills.name: Identifying functions from ordered pairs, mappings and tables

explanations.A: f(x) means a function, f, is applied to the variable, x. The function here is to multiply x by 7 and then add 6.
explanations.B: Terms of x don't include an equals sign. 7x on its own would be a term.
explanations.C: Identities of x are two expressions that are equal for all values of x. So for example 3x + 12 and 3(x + 4) are identities of each other.
explanations.D: Almost! A formula would have an equals sign but this notation f(x) is not typically used to indicate a formula.

explanations.A: Almost! f(x) is a function but is it a function of y?
explanations.B: This is an equation but this is not written using function notation.
explanations.C: f(y) means a function, f, is applied to the variable, y. The function here is to multiply y by -2 and add 4.
explanations.D: This is an expression in terms of y, not a function of y.

explanations.A: Not quite, this set of ordered pairs does represent a function. Every input (x) has at most one output (y).
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you are confused with the definition of function. A function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). This means that within a set of ordered pairs, we can have the same output value BUT not the same input value.
explanations.C: Not quite, this set of ordered pairs does represent a function. Every input (x) has at most one output (y).
explanations.D: A function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). In this set, an input of 1 is mapped to four different ouput values. Therefore it does not represent a function.

explanations.A: Not quite, this set of ordered pairs does represent a function. Every input (x) has at most one output (y).
explanations.B: Not quite, this set of ordered pairs does represent a function. Every input (x) has at most one output (y).
explanations.C: A function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). In this set, an input of 1 is mapped to two different ouput values. Therefore it does not represent a function.
explanations.D: Not quite. I think you are confused with the definition of function. A function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). This means that within a set of ordered pairs, we can have the same output value BUT not the same input value.

explanations.A: This mapping is a function as each input is mapped to only one output.
explanations.B: Not quite. Look carefully at the number of arrows coming out of each input. A function will have at most one arrow attatched to every input value.
explanations.C: Not quite. Look carefully at the number of arrows coming out of each input. A function will have at most one arrow attatched to every input value.
explanations.D: Not quite. Look carefully at the number of arrows coming out of each input. A function will have at most one arrow attatched to every input value.

explanations.A: Not quite. This mapping is a function as each input is mapped to only one output. A mapping wouldn't be a function if the same input had arrows connecting it to more than one output value.
explanations.B: Not quite. This is a function, as a function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). Different inputs can be mapped to the same output BUT the same input cannot be mapped to more than one output.
explanations.C: Not quite. This mapping is a function as each input is mapped to only one output. A mapping wouldn't be a function if the same input had arrows connecting it to more than one output value.
explanations.D: This mapping is not a function as some of the inputs are mapped to more than one output.

explanations.A: Not quite. This table represents a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y).
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you are confused with the definition of function. A function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). Different inputs can be mapped to the same output BUT the same input cannot be mapped to more than one output.
explanations.C: A function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). In this table, an input of 1 is mapped to four different ouput values. Therefore it does not represent a function.
explanations.D: Not quite. This table represents a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y).

explanations.A: Not quite. This table represents a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y).
explanations.B: Not quite. I think you are confused with the definition of function. A function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). Different inputs can be mapped to the same output BUT the same input cannot be mapped to more than one output.
explanations.C: Not quite. This table represents a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y).
explanations.D: A function maps every input (x) to at most one output (y). In this table, an input of 5 is mapped to four different ouput values. Therefore it does not represent a function.

explanations.A: Not quite. This graph represents a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y). You can check this by using the vertical line test.
explanations.B: This graph does not represent a function as there are some inputs (x) that have more than one output (y). Moving a vertical line across the graph, shows that there are some x values that correspond to more than one y value.
explanations.C: Not quite. This graph represents a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y). You can check this by using the vertical line test.
explanations.D: Not quite. This graph represents a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y). You can check this by using the vertical line test.

explanations.A: Not quite. This graph does not represent a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y). You can check this by using the vertical line test.
explanations.B: Not quite. This graph does not represent a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y). You can check this by using the vertical line test.
explanations.C: This graph does represent a function as every input (x) has at most one output (y). Moving a vertical line across the graph, shows that there are no values of x that correspond to more than one y value.
explanations.D: Not quite. This graph does not represent a function. Remember, to be a function, every input (x) has at most one output (y). You can check this by using the vertical line test.
